text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ADI IGNATIUS: Welcome
to HBR Quarantine.

I'm Adi Ignatius, Editor in
Chief of Harvard Business
Review.

My cohost is Josh Macht,
our C-Suite guy in charge
of product and innovation.

Our special guest
today is going to be

Anthony Fauci, America's
foremost spokesperson
in the fight against COVID-19.

This is our last
show for the season.

We're going to take a
break for the rest of July
and for all of August.

We'd love to know what you
think of the show, what
we could do better.

And be sure, as always,
to put in questions

for our guest in
the comment box.

So let me just do a quick
read from our partner.

Support for this program
comes from Medtronic,
a medical technology leader.

Guided by its mission to
alleviate pain, restore health,

and extend life, Medtronic
is bringing the power

of medical technology to
help healthcare professionals
respond to COVID-19.

Learn more about
Medtronic's efforts,

including how they've
contributed to the global

ventilator supply, at
Medtronic.com/covid19.

So without further
ado, it's my pleasure
to introduce Dr. Anthony Fauci.

He is a man who currently
needs no introduction.

He is Director of the
National Institute of Allergy

and Infectious Diseases, a
job he's held for 36 years,

serving under six US
presidents and working

at the forefront of
efforts to confront

viral diseases like HIV/AIDS,
SARS, swine flu, Ebola,
and others.

He's now America's
top spokesperson
on the COVID-19 pandemic.

And in that role, he has
become an international star.

There's now an Anthony Fauci
bobblehead and a plush toy
with a superhero cape.

In other words, America's
biggest rock star
is an immunologist.

As you know, we always like to
show a TikTok video each week.

So here's one from
a doctor fan that
illustrates the phenomenon.

[MUSIC - JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE
 "SEXYBACK"]
To the chorus.
Come here, girl.
Go 'head, be gone with it.
Come to the back.
Go 'head, be gone with it.
VIP.
Go 'head, be gone with it.
Drinks on me.
Go 'head, be gone with it.

You see what you're
twerking with.
Go 'head, be gone with it.
Look at those hips.
Go 'head, be gone with it.

ADI IGNATIUS: So
welcome, Dr. Fauci.

As you can see, you've
touched a lot of people.
ANTHONY FAUCI: Wow.

JOSHUA MACHT: You
hadn't seen that one?

ADI IGNATIUS: Let
me dive right in.

So at this moment, we're seeing
a resurgence in cases, COVID-19
cases, in parts of the US.

The European Union
is restricting travel
by Americans.

My question for you is,
what is wrong with us?

Is American sense of
individual freedom

simply incompatible with
a prudent health response?

ANTHONY FAUCI: You know, I think
there's no doubt that that's
part of the process.

It's probably much more
complicated than that.

But if you would have asked me
what the one thing that I think

is common about it, it's
exactly what you said.

You know, when the European
Union shut down at the time

when they went to lockdown,
as it were, about 95% or more

of the country
truly locked down.

When we were in our lockdown,
about 50% of the country
was in lockdown.

So at the time when their curves
peaked and then went way down,

ours peaked and then
kind of stayed like this,

which where they've been
for the last several weeks
to a couple of months.

And now what we're seeing,
in an attempt to open,

which, in many respects, we
never really completely closed.

We're starting to see what,
unfortunately, is that rather
robust spike back up.

Yesterday there was
over 50,000 new cases,

which is something
that's really going

to be a persistent problem
unless we attack it

in a different way than
we're attacking it right now.

JOSHUA MACHT: Well, that's
the question, Dr. Fauci.
You know, you see these spikes.

It is pretty scary
and inconsistent
all over the country.

What should the government
or could the government
do from a federal point of view?
What could it be doing better?

I mean, should we have a
stronger federal response
or national response?

ANTHONY FAUCI: You know, that's
the ongoing debate and tension

about the very special nature
of how the founding fathers
developed our country.

You know, the federalism,
the states' rights,

giving the states the
options to do things

in a way that's
peculiar and specific

to their particular region
of the country, you know,

in some respects
works very well.

But one can make an
argument, and many people

have, that we do need
more central direction,
central control.

But boy, that's a very,
very hotly disputed area.
I can tell you that.
I think you already know that.

But I think you can make
very compelling arguments
on either side.

But whatever it is, we're
seeing such disparate responses

among the different states,
among the different regions,

among the different cities,
that it's very, very

difficult to be able
to put something
in a unidimensional fashion.

It just doesn't happen that
way, probably to our detriment.

ADI IGNATIUS: There's also a
split along political lines.

And I'm sure you
don't want to be
drawn into a political battle.

You survived six
presidents, after all.

But faith in experts
like yourself does

seem to break in part
along political lines.

And put simply, Democrats
seem to trust experts like you
more than Republicans do.

How do you interpret that and
how do you cope with that?

ANTHONY FAUCI:
Well, first of all,

you have to cope with
that, because it's

a reality of what's
going on right now.

One of the big
difficulties is that when

you have such political
divisiveness that we have right

now, it's very, very difficult
to get a clear, crisp message

across when you have leaders who
are very, very different in how

they interpret what's
going on and what

the primary goal of
where you want to go.

It's really not a
unified response.

And you don't need
me to tell you that.

You just need to look at
what's going on in the country.

That makes it very
difficult to do

the kinds of things you need
to do from a public health
standpoint.

JOSHUA MACHT: When
you talk, everyone
is hanging on every word.

And we're curious to the
extent that when, you know,

are you making recommendations
purely as a medical expert?

Meaning preaching
maximum caution,

or are you thinking about
the weight of your words

and trying to balance
the medical necessity
with social needs?

ANTHONY FAUCI: You know, I
always try to do a balance.

But I'm very often being
put in a position where

I'm asked for my
strict medical advice

interpretation of the patterns
of the disease you're seeing,

what it might mean if we go in
one direction versus the other.

And I always give my very
honest opinion and advice

if I'm asked for
advice, but I certainly

let the evidence, and
the facts, and the data
guide what I tell people.

Now, I think that something
that people don't understand

is when you're dealing
with a situation

where the entire
country is involved,

that there are
people who clearly

come from a different
perspective than I do.

They have a very,
very heavy focus

on the economy, or on
things like jobs, and things

like that, which
are important to me

as an individual
citizen in the country.

But I'm not asked
to give an opinion

that has economic impact or not,
or that has jobs impact or not.

I'm being asked to give
my opinion vis-a-vis
the pure health issues.

Others will take an opinion
from me or an opinion

from one of the economists,
Larry Kudlow, Steve Mnuchin,

and others, and then weigh
it and then make a decision.

So even though I'm sensitive
to the economic issues,
that's not my job to do it.

My job is to give just a pure
public health evaluation.

I mean, for example, what I
was saying that, you know,
you've got to take your choice.

If you want to open
up the government

and get back to
more normality, I

am aware, apropos of the
question that you asked,

of what economic impact a
certain direction will take us.

So it isn't as if I'm
completely blind to that.
I understand that.

But what I try to do is to
get people to understand
that they're not extremes.

It's almost as if there's
the public health approach,

and then there's the
devil may care approach.

They're polar opposites,
but they don't need to be.

I keep saying that for
those, including myself,

who are interested in
the economic impact,

and the impact on jobs, and
the impact on employment,

on the impact on the economy in
general, that you should make

the public health
measures be a vehicle

to opening the country,
not an obstacle
to opening the country.

And I think an
example of that is

that when certain
states decided, even

within the realm of the right
recommendations, to open up,

we saw the citizenry of some
of the regions of the country

immediately say, OK, we're no
longer locked down, so let's

storm the bars, go to the
beaches, go to crowds.

And then you see that
peak that goes up.

So, I mean, I think
that's counterproductive.

Because it's almost
like, OK, you've

relieved me of the public
health constraints.
Now I can do whatever I want.
No.
There has to be a balance.

And even though I'm a
public health person,

I'm acutely aware you
have to have the balance.

You have to be
sensitive and aware

of the importance of public
health constraining issues.

On the other hand, you can't
always say, if it doesn't work,

let's lock the
government down again.

We can't be just
locking it down,

because then we'll have
secondary consequences that

are going to be really
quite consequential.

ADI IGNATIUS: So if
you just joined us,
this is HBR Quarantine.
Our guest is Dr. Anthony Fauci.
Quick plug.

Visit our Healthcare and
Pandemic Insight Center

on HBR.org, which is
sponsored by Medtronic.

So Dr. Fauci, this is a
classic HBR-type question.

Do you have advice for viewers
about telling your boss

something that he or she
doesn't want to hear?

How do you approach a
conversation like that?

ANTHONY FAUCI: Well, I mean,
it depends on the circumstances
that you're in.

I know I could give
you a personal example.

I made a decision
the very first time

I walked into the White
House during the Reagan
administration.

And it was something that
was part of my own way

that I've been brought
up by my family

and by my education, which was
in very intellectual Jesuitical

Catholic elementary--
not elementary,

but high school
and college, about

the importance of public
service, and the truth,

and the rigor of
science and evidence.

So with that as a
background, I made a decision

that when you go
into a situation

and you have to tell people
things that they might not

like to hear, you've
got to be able to make

the sacrifice that that
person might not ever

ask you for advice again, or you
might not ever ask back again.

So the first time I went
into the White House, which

was the 1980s, the early
'80s, I take the same attitude
as I take right now.
I'm going to tell the truth.

And a lot of times, that's
going to be something a person
doesn't want to hear.

So you've got to be
aware of the fact

that person might
not ask you back.

And what happens if you
do that, what happens

is that people know
that you're not being
partisan one way or the other.
You're just telling the truth.

That people gain respect for
you and they do ask you back.

And that's probably
the reason why

I have been doing this with so
many different administrations.

JOSHUA MACHT: So I want to pivot
to the vaccine for a second
here.

You've been on the record
as cautiously optimistic.

We recently-- I think
we're seeing that--

you said that, even as
early as this winter,

we would really have
the knowledge of,

are we on to something
that's safe and effective.
A couple of things.

One is, what does
effective mean for you?
What is the bar here?

And then the second
thing is, because, you

know, it goes hand in
hand with eventually

having so many people
being willing to take

this vaccine, what is the
government going to do

or preparing to do to
ensure, with so much

antivaccine sentiment out there
and the headwind, you know,
it feels like a huge challenge.

What's the government
going to do

and planning to do to ensure
that it's widely distributed?
ANTHONY FAUCI: OK.
Two very good questions.

Yes, with the caveat
that you're never

going to be able to
guarantee, when you're

dealing with vaccines, that's
just the nature of vaccinology,

that you're going to have a
safe and effective vaccine.

But the early
preliminary data on what

several of these
candidates can induce,

they can induce the
kind of immune response

that you would predict
would be protective.

But to your specific question,
what is success, what does
that mean.

For the most part, I
mean, the perfect thing

would be to have a vaccine
that completely protects you
against infection.

It's called
sterilizing immunity.
You don't get infected at all.

But what we would accept
gladly is a vaccine

that, when administered
and a person

gets exposed and infected,
they don't get sick.

In other words,
to prevent someone

from getting a clinically
recognizable or clinically

important disease that
would require the attention
of a healthcare provider.

So you may have a low level
smoldering infection that
doesn't bother you very much.

If we had 70% of the
efficacy of people

who get to that
end point, I would
be very satisfied with that.
Will we get there?
No guarantee.

I think there's a reasonably
good chance we will.

The timeframe is really going
to depend on how many infections

there are in the
community to allow

you to be able to prove
that it is both safe
and also effective.

So if we get to that point by
the end of this calendar year,

into the first quarter of
2021, that would be good
and that would be success.

Your second question,
how do you get people

in an era of antiscience,
which kind of spills over

into antivax, to
take a vaccine when

there's a lot of skepticism
about government,
about authority?

I think it's essential,
I know it's essential,

to do what we call community
outreach and community
engagement.

To start now, to get
people to understand

in a very transparent way, why
it will be important to get

vaccinated when we have
a vaccine that we know
is safe and effective.

We need to also put particular
effort into the most vulnerable
communities.

And in many respects, the most
[? invulnerable ?] communities

are those who have every
reason, in some respect,

to not necessarily
trust authority.

People who have been
disenfranchised,
including minority populations.

African-Americans, Latinx,
Native Americans, and others.

Because when you look at the
statistics, those are the ones,

demographically, that
are at the greatest risk

of serious complications
of COVID-19.

ADI IGNATIUS: So let's
talk some more about risk.

So there are people who took
what seemed like huge risks

going to the Tulsa
rally for Trump,

or were taking part
in street protests.
Are we seeing that cohort?

Are we seeing those people
get sick at a concerning rate,
or are they somehow not?

ANTHONY FAUCI: You know,
it's very difficult.

Given all the other things that
are going on simultaneously

with the protest demonstrations,
with the political rallies,

with the holiday of Memorial
Day four weeks or so ago,

with the opening of certain
states to so-called normalize
back.

All those things were
confluent together.

So it's very
difficult to say that

this particular demonstration,
or that particular rally,

or that particular
holiday at a beach did it.

But something happened to make
the spike go way up like that.

So I think you have to be
suspicious of every single one

of the elements that
you just mentioned.

And it is likely that
there was a contribution,

to a greater or lesser
degree, of all of those.

But we can't really pinpoint
it, because everything
was conflated.
ADI IGNATIUS: Let me just do--
as a quick follow up.
You know, the cases are up.

And it's not just testing,
I appreciate that.

But the mortality
rate seems to be down.

And I guess the question
is, has coronavirus,

has it perhaps mutated into
a form that maybe is not
much worse than the flu?

ANTHONY FAUCI: Well,
that's always possible.

But I think that's unlikely to
explain the phenomenon that you
just described.

If you look at the demography
age-wise of the people that

are getting infected, that
are responsible for that spike

that we see, they're
about a decade

and a half younger than
the people who got infected

and were responsible
for the hospitalizations

and deaths a few
months ago when we

saw New York, and
Boston, and New Orleans,
and Chicago hit so hard.

So I think the reason
is that you're not now.

But a few weeks
from now, you might.

You're not seeing as
many hospitalizations,

and certainly not a
sharp spike in deaths.

Younger people are
getting infected.

And probably, we've
learned the lesson

of what it means to protect
the vulnerable, particularly

people in nursing homes,
which really accounted

for a disproportionately high
number of the hospitalizations

and deaths, certainly
the deaths, of people

who, for any of a
number of reasons,
were in a nursing home.

Right now you're seeding
younger people getting infected.

But the one thing we need to
realize, that if you're young

and you get infected, and even
though you have no symptoms,

you are part of the dynamic
process of an outbreak.

And although you may think
you're living in a vacuum

and your infection is going
to have no impact on others,
that's not true.

Because you will likely
inadvertently and even

innocently infect
someone else, who

will infect someone
else, who then
will infect a vulnerable person.

Someone's grandmother,
or grandfather,

or uncle who's
getting chemotherapy
for a neoplastic disease.

And that person will be the
one that's in the hospital
and dies.
So we're a continuum.

We're a part of a
dynamic process.

And I think that's
one of the things that

confuses people who feel,
I'm probably invulnerable.
I'm young.

My colleagues get
infected, my friends,
and they don't really get sick.
Doesn't matter.

You're lucky that
you don't get sick.
Young people can get sick.

But you are part of the
spread of a pandemic.

That's the issue you
really need to understand.

And to me, that's a
societal responsibility
that you can't run away from.

JOSHUA MACHT: Well,
that makes sense.

Help us here with the whole
idea first wave and next waves,

because I think, at
least for myself,

it's easy to lose the
thread with all the spikes
that are going on.

But thinking about business
going forward into the fall,

what's the thinking,
the latest thinking
now, on what a second wave--

when would that be and
what would that look like?

ANTHONY FAUCI: Well, Josh,
that's a great question.

But that relates historically
to the 1918 outbreak.

When in the spring,
there was a sprinkling

of infections that was
clearly dangerous because it

was a pandemic that
was killing people.
And then it kind of disappeared.

I mean, literally
disappeared in the summer.

And then it came back
with the roar of a lion
in the fall and the winter.

That was what we referred
to as the second wave.

We should not be thinking
about a second wave.

We are still knee deep
in the first wave.
Take a look at the curve.

For us in the United
States, it went up,

it kind of flattened out,
and it stayed that way
for weeks, and weeks, and weeks.

And now it's going right
back up and peaking.

So there's no such a thing as
a second wave for us right now.
We're still in the first wave.

ADI IGNATIUS: So I
have one more question,

then I want to take
some from our viewers.

The debate about the
origin of the virus

is likely to gather steam
in the coming months

as we head toward an election,
with some voices charged

that it was created in
China, and then released

either accidentally or even
on purpose from a lab there.

What is the science
telling you about that?

ANTHONY FAUCI: This is a virus
that is very, very commonly

seen in bats that are
in China, for sure,

as well as other
intermediate hosts of it.

The way the phylogenetic
tracing of this

was that this was evolving
in the environment
for a very long period of time.

And there's every
reason to believe

that it did what the
original SARS did

and what MERS, the Middle
East Respiratory Syndrome,

did, both of which
are coronaviruses

that had jumped species,
perhaps to an intermediate host.
We don't know what that host is.

And then started efficiently
affecting humans.

There's no evidence at all
that anybody created this.

It was naturally in
the environment in bats

in a very, very similar virus
to what we're seeing right now.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.

I'm going to go to a
question from a viewer.

This is from
Philippe from Bogota.

The question is, would
it be beneficial to allow

nonvulnerable populations to
slowly and carefully go back

to their lives and to
try to get immunity,

or protecting the most
vulnerable portion
while we wait for a vaccine?

ANTHONY FAUCI: Well, the first
part of that question I liked,

was to get the nonvulnerable
people while you're protecting

the vulnerable to
go back to some

degree of normality of opening
up businesses and culture.
That's a good thing.

But the question used
a very important word,

to carefully and
prudently go back,

which is the whole fundamental
basis of the guidelines
for opening America again.

Where you have
checkpoints so that,

in the region that
you're at, you

have to have a certain
diminution of the infections.
Then you get to phase one.

If you stay controlled and
come down, you go to phase two.

That's exactly what
we wanted to see.

Unfortunately, that's
not what happened.

What happened is that it became
an all or none phenomenon.

It's that some people
interpreted opening up as just
going out and devil may care.

And I think that's one
of the things that's
contributing to the spike.

But as far as herd
immunity goes,

you have to get 70% plus
of the population infected
for herd immunity.

So that's not a
good idea to think

you're going to get 70%
of the population infected
and then you'll be OK.

The Brits tried
that, didn't work.

The Swedes tried that,
didn't work very well.

ADI IGNATIUS: So here's,
actually, a couple of people
are posing the question.

This is Elizabeth from New York
City and Tomiko from Alabama.

And really, the question
is, if you were in charge,

would you open schools and
universities this fall?

ANTHONY FAUCI: You
know, the answer

is, you can't
answer that question

as a country because of the
extraordinary heterogeneity.
It cannot be unidimensional.

For example, there'll be
regions of the country

where the viral dynamics are
so profound that it would
be very dangerous to do that.

There are other regions of
the country, counties where
there's almost no infection.

Where, with no trouble at all,
you can open up the schools

you've got to look at the
level of viral activity

in the location where you're at,
least for the non university,
non college.

And then depending upon
the degree of infection,
you make modifications.

You could either
open them completely

or it's too dangerous
to open them.

Which I think we'd
better be careful,

because I think we
should do everything

we possibly can to get the
children back to school

safely because of the unintended
deleterious consequences of not

getting them to be in school,
the ripple effects on family
and things like that.

But if you're going
to be opening them

and you have enough
activity in your community,

there are ways of
mitigating that.

Alternating schedules, morning
for some, afternoon for others.

Alternate days, classrooms
that are essentially

a single teacher rather
than having teachers change.

Very creative ways that
many of the principals

and superintendents
of the school
are trying to figure out.

ADI IGNATIUS: Actually,
so quick follow up.

If you were the
commissioner of all sports,

would you restart the NBA, Major
League Baseball, and the NFL?
ANTHONY FAUCI: Yeah.

I can't give you a
short answer to that,
but I'll give you a precise one.

I can give advice to what the
dynamics of the outbreak are

and what the public
health reality is.

I can't make recommendations
on whether this sport

of that sport should start
a stop, or whatever you do.
The fundamental principles.

If you're going
to do that, there

are two elements you've
got to be thinking of.

The safety and the
welfare of the players.

Because they're going
to be very enthusiastic
about their sports.
That's their livelihood.
That's their life.

You've got to make sure we
don't put them in harm's way.

And number two, what
you do about spectators?

Can you do it in an area where
there's a lot of infection?
How do you do that?
Do you have only television?
Do you have stadiums half full?

There are multiple
iterations of that.

You know, and as I mentioned
that the hearing, the Senate

hearing the other day when
Senator Rand Paul, maybe tongue

in cheek, but maybe
not, was telling me why
I wanted to stop all sports.
I don't want to stop all sports.
I'm really a sports fan.

But I think we need to do it
with safety and with prudence.

Remember, you have
people's lives here.

You don't want to
just jeopardize them.

JOSHUA MACHT: Very
quickly, because we
know your time is limited.

So for the states
like Massachusetts

that have started to
see these big declines,

and I think a few
days ago we had

zero deaths in
Massachusetts, you

said that's a big time
lagging indicator.

Looking forward in
these areas, what's

the most important
leading indicator?

What do you look at
as the areas that, you

know, an indicator that says
these areas are starting
to tick up again?
ANTHONY FAUCI: Yeah.

You are going to see infections
as we try to open up and go
from one phase to another.

By the way, Massachusetts has
done a really, really good job.
They have.

New York City, even though
they got hit really badly,

did a really good job
of getting it down.

What you look at is what
the percentage of the tests
that you do are positive.

In other words, people say,
well, you see more cases
if you do more tests.
Yeah.

That, sometimes,
is a red herring.

It's the percentage
of the positives.

If you can keep
that down, when you

start to see the
percentage of the tests

you do that are positive,
